text: all my experience with my father for the
first few few years of my life four of a
kind man and a humorous man who is very
engaging in his family it wasn't until
about seven years old that I started to
notice he was much more impatient and
quicker to anger and he also started
spending less time with his family and
more time a mosque with the men who
would ultimately would be responsible
for the World Trade Center bombing in
1993 what was there an attempt to
indoctrinate you certainly as he says he
started spending less time at home the
time that he did spend with me was
usually at the mosque listening to
sermons given by the blind Sheikh Omar
Berman or listening to him discuss
religion and politics with the other men
involved I was essentially taught that
anyone outside of this very narrow
ideology that he followed was a
potential danger and a potential threat
to me and so I grew up harboring many
negative stereotypes about all kinds of
different people could you just tell us
a little bit about those stereotypes or
what what it was that he was saying to
you well as I said essentially that
anyone outside of the ideology that he
followed was there in order to try and
make me sin because they were going to
hell and so they were trying to drag me
to hell with them you know I've been
taught that Jews and Muslims could not
coexist with one another that they were
natural enemies that homosexuality was a
sin and it really took my being exposed
to the outside world and interacting
with these kinds of people to realize
that what I've been taught as a child
was in fact a lie did you meet any of
these other jihadists yourself and the
especially the mastermind of the 1993
bombing of the World Trade Center
yes I'd met all of them on several
occasions my father would take me out of
school early on Fridays so that I could
go listen to shitty Barbara and give his
sermon during Friday prayer I interacted
with many of the men involved in the
World Trade Center bombing in fact one
of them after my father had gone to
prison initially for the assassination
of my ahkahuna one of the men had told
him that he wanted to marry my sister
when she became when she came of age as
a sign of I guess respect and solidarity
with my father's actions do you have any
relationship now with your father or are
you in contact with him you know for
years I visited him in prison and we
talked on the phone constantly and about
when I was about 17 I decided to change
my name and disconnect communication
with my father the first time I ever
gave a speech publicly actually was a
Southwestern University in Texas and
when I arrived at my hotel room that
evening there was an email from my
father's lawyer saying that my father
had been looking for me for many years
and would like to be in contact with me
long story short he and I began email
communication a few years ago because I
had questions as to you know why he
chose this action over his family and
his family's well-being and I wanted him
to understand how hard it was for our
family after he left but unfortunately
he summed it up with essentially that it
was all God's plan and I'm no longer a
Muslim and he said that if I would just
join the religion again that all of my
problems would be solved which was
obviously not something that I wanted to
hear so I decided to discontinue
communication with him again you also
say there were times when you believed
what your father was saying was right
well when you're a child you know you
don't have the ability to determine
what's right and what's wrong you accept
what your family teaches you as the
truth and it took many years of
conscious effort to rid myself of this
almost
I don't want to say natural because it's
completely unnatural but this this way
of looking at the world and judging
everyone around you based on these very
constraining precepts and it really as I
said once I became exposed to the people
that I'd been taught these stereotypes
about and found them to be quite
different than I had been raised to
believe that I was able to shed many of
those beliefs one of the reasons that I
wrote this book was because I wanted to
give people insight into what it was
like growing up in this ideology and
what experiences and the lessons that I
learned from them that brought me out of
it but it was also very important for me
although I'm no longer Muslim I wanted
to show people that my experience was
unique among Muslims that the vast
majority of Muslims in the world are not
exposed to this this level of extremism
and so if I could come out of it
promoting peace and non-violence and
accepting of other people then what does
that say about the vast majority of
Muslims in the world how difficult was
it for you to ultimately reject what
your father was saying and break away
from it you know there was never any
defining moment where I realized that I
was not going to follow down this path
it was really an incremental process
having a conversation with a friend
about homosexuals and realizing that my
views different from from his and and
because I experienced bullying very
badly as a child and I was very well
aware of what it meant to be victimized
for things that were beyond my control
whether it was because of my father's
actions or because my name sounded funny
I was born as Jesus saying no ser not
Zak Ibrahim so that's a bit of a
mouthful for you know for a westerner
and and so there was there are many
reasons that I had been bullied for
things that I that I had no control over
and I knew very intimately what that
felt like and so when it came time for
me to perpetuate this same sort of
treatment on people that I had been
taught were bad I couldn't bring myself
to do it simply because they weren't
they were kind and
non-judgemental of me when you know
certainly there were reasons for them to
be what do you make of the current
situation in Iraq and Syria and
especially the recruitment of many young
men and women from the West well I think
it's important that we have a sense of
proportion there are millions of Muslims
in the United States there are tens of
millions more Muslims in Europe and
we're talking about you know a number in
the in the hundreds or very low
thousands that's not to say that it's
not a threat that it's not a you know
dangerous but I think groups like Isis
are not the problem they are a symptom
of the problem the instability in that
region the dictatorships the violent
governments that often battle these
groups and leave very little opportunity
for those in the middle who would just
like to work and raise their families in
safety and provide an education for
their families these are the vast
majority of people and we lose sight of
the majority of people when you know
when when all we're talking about is
Isis and and and this potential threat
